value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">29</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">plays <add hand="typewriter" place="above">writing</add> a general nature.
            <choice>
              <sic>t</sic>
              <corr>It</corr>
            </choice> gave us the 
            <choice>
              <sic>ballds</sic>
              <corr>ballads</corr>
            </choice>; it gave</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">us the 
            <choice>
              <sic>somgs</sic>
              <corr>songs</corr>
            </choice>. It allowed us to know nothing of the mans</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">name. <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> had great privileges. He is not responsible.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can repeat.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He can say what everyone feels. No one asks that he shall</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">stamp his own name on his work. He keeps at a distance from</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the present moment. Anon the lyric writer 
            <choice>
              <sic>repeat</sic>
              <corr>repeats</corr>
            </choice> over and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>ove</sic>
              <corr>over</corr>
            </choice> again that flowers fade; that death is the end.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He is never tired of 
            <choice>
              <sic>clebrating</sic>
              <corr>celebrating</corr>
            </choice> red roses and the white</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>bresast</sic>
              <corr>breast</corr>
            </choice> of his mistress. The anonymous dxmxmxmxmxmx</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">playwright has like the singer this 
            <choice>
              <sic>namless</sic>
              <corr>nameless</corr>
            </choice> vitality.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">something drawn from the crowd in the penny seats. and not</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">yet dead in 
            <choice>
              <sic>ouslves</sic>
              <corr>ourselves</corr>
            </choice>. For we too have become 
            <choice>
              <sic>aninymous</sic>
              <corr>anonymous</corr>
            </choice>, and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">forget something that we have learnt, in reading the plays</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that no one troubled to set a name to.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Later when the audience becomes critical, when the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">emotion in the audience becomes self 
            <choice>
              <sic>oncsious</sic>
              <corr>conscious</corr>
            </choice>, when</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the country squire can say without quoting <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> what</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is in his mind, we lose this general quality to gain---</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">everything it 
            <choice>
              <sic>seemes</sic>
              <corr>seems</corr>
            </choice>. For until the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-puri" key="Puritans">puritans</rs> shut the 
            <choice>
              <sic>thea</sic>
              <corr>theatre</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the 
            <choice>
              <sic>curayin</sic>
              <corr>curtain</corr>
            </choice> rises 
            <choice>
              <sic>incesaantly</sic>
              <corr>incessantly</corr>
            </choice>. It goes on rising until</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">finally it rises on the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-temp" key="Tempest, The">Tempest</rs>. But by then the stage has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">become too small for the play. It has outgrown the uncovered</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">theatre where 
            <choice>
              <sic>eh</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> sun beats and the rain pours. And the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reader is born. He acts the play in the theatre of his own</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">brain. Perhaps after centuries the play is born again,</l>
